Expectation1: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation1: The nun has been chosen to represent the convent and lead a prayer vigil at a major public religious event.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story:
I woke before dawn, the convent still wrapped in silence. Today, I was to lead the prayer vigil at the cathedral—a rare honor, and one my sisters expected me to fulfill with devotion and grace. My heart swelled with gratitude, but a knot of anxiety tightened in my chest. My volunteer shift at the shelter started at the same time as the vigil. I knew the others could cover for me if I was late, but I prided myself on reliability. The shelter’s guests, many of whom had come to trust my presence, would notice my absence. 

As I dressed in my habit, I felt the weight of both roles pressing down. The convent needed me to be a model of faith, present and unwavering. The shelter needed me to be dependable, a steady hand in the chaos. I could not be in two places at once. My mind raced with guilt and worry, torn between the expectations of my calling and my commitment to serve. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, heart pounding, uncertain which door I would walk through.
